author: China Insights
description:
Censorship Fails! The Yu Menglong Story Burns Hotter the More It’s Banned. Fans’ self-made animation “Bai Zhen the High God’s Tribulation” uses xianxia to mirror reality; the line “If truth cannot be spoken, let light speak for me” has become an online catchphrase. UK medium TY William says she was pressured across borders after her revelations. The AVAAZ global petition has surpassed 430,000 signatures and is racing toward 500,000, with international support surging like a tide. Inside the firewall there’s a blackout; outside, an awakening—how far are we from the truth in this “tribulation of light”? title: Censorship Fails: Yu Case Goes ViralBan Backfires—Truth Spreads

author: China Insights
description:
A total internet blackout—and yet Yu Menglong’s popularity is surging on Bilibili. Posts are deleted on Weibo, topics are cooled down, but Bilibili alone is “heating in reverse.” Someone claiming to be a content reviewer says directives from the Central Propaganda Department and the Cyberspace Administration are at odds; at the same time, director Cheng Qingsong posted three Weibo messages on Qiao Renliang’s heavenly birthday, stirring public shock.Don’t miss the next drop—subscribe and enable the bell.

title: Bilibili “Breaks Ranks”: Yu Menglong Case Roars Back as Director’s Posts Ignite a Firestorm

author: China Insights
description:
With only four days until the CCP’s Fourth Plenum, Beijing’s political scene has suddenly heated up—two “Hu-surnamed figures” appeared in high profile almost simultaneously: Hu Chunhua headed to Xinjiang’s “minefields,” while Hu Haifeng seized state-media headlines. One south, one north; one elder, one younger—images surfacing in sync. Coincidence? Or a political signal before the Plenum? Hu Chunhua sharing a front page with Wang Huning, and Hu Haifeng “appearing out of order” ahead of a minister—does this signal a revival of the League faction, or an internal power test inside Zhongnanhai? title: Hu Chunhua Steps into Xinjiang, Hu Haifeng Takes the Spotlight

author: China Insights
description:
“Even grief must be reported.” In 2025 China, this sentence is becoming reality. A Shanghai petitioner, Yu Zhonghuan, was soft-detained and cut off from food; homeowners defending their rights in Guangdong were “lured” into arrest; the pastor and congregants of Beijing’s Zion Church were detained en masse; and online tributes to Yu Menglong are labeled “negative emotions” and scrubbed wholesale. From speech censorship and suppression of faith to unified control over “emotion” itself—the CCP has entered an unprecedented era of emotional totalitarianism.
